climbs.name: You're Busted
climbs.fa: Glenn Schuler, Mark Milligan, Kevin McLaughlin

content.description: This is a really nice climb, that deserves more traffic.  Take a line of edges and pockets past the initial face into a scoop.  The scoop is a nice place to take a breath before tip toeing up to the lightly pocketed wall above.
content.protection: Six bolts to chain anchors.
content.location:
This is located a dozen routes or so to the right of

Ligneous Embracer

, just right of Penal Code (12c).  It is just on the right side of a rounded bulge, giving it shade in early afternoon, unlike a few of its neighbors to the left.  Ascend from bushes up a initially broken face into pockets, up into a scoop, and finally through a pocketed wall to a horizontal crack just below the lip and anchors.

content.description: A tenuous boulder problem on small holds gets you to the first jug hueco. Pull on small pockets (crux) to reach the steep section that leads to the crack.
content.protection: 5 bolts and 2 bolt Mussy hook anchor. New ASCA bolts were installed in 2020.
content.location:
It is to the left of

Scratch 'N' Sniff

.

content.description:
Climb clean .5/.4 corner crack that start in a flared roof.

The anchor is all the way at the top of the formation on the left side of the chimney.
content.protection: TCUs and small to medium Friends.
content.location:
It ascends the super clean corner crack right of

U2RINXS

.

content.description: A short face climb in a nice little secluded side canyon.  Not remarkable, but worth doing to warm up. This is Route #85 in D'Antonio (1999:46), although no topos are in the guide book.
content.protection:
3 bolts to a 2-bolt top anchor with chains (shared with the

Big Brett

route to the right).
content.location: From the roadside parking area, this route is in the first side canyon on the left, ca. 125 yards from the road. Follow the side canyon about 55 yards to a nice Ponderosa pine near the canyon head.  Just past the pine, and before you come to a nice spruce/fir, turn left into a tributary canyon.  Pass about 10 yards through some chokecherry, and the face is on the righthand side of the canyon.  Wallrus ascends the lefthand side of the little face.  A slightly overhanging crack with cold-shut anchors at the top is just to the left of the Wallrus face.

content.description:
Start up a slab and left-leaning crack to a slight bulge. Power through the bulge, alternating between the crack and sweet crimps, sidepulls, and pockets on the face, then trend back to the right through the crux and up to the chains.

It is a good warm-up.
content.protection: It is newly equipped with glue-in bolts and Mussy hooks at the anchor.
content.location:
This is tucked back in a slight alcove a little above and west of the main trail, adjacent to

Honeycomb

.

content.description: Start under the bulge, then move into the horizontal crack. Follow the crack around to the right, use the face some, and then move up left onto the bulge, finishing with moves up high on hollow grips.
content.protection: Be careful, and be willing to choose to back down and have the downclimbing ability to support that decision.
content.location: From the parking Rock Garden parking lot, follow the west side of the west cliff span, heading SW (or find your way from inside the canyon). Eventually find a small clearing in the cliffspan (listed as the "Fairie Grotto" by Phillip Benningfield in his Colorado Bouldering Mountains book). On the very NW side of the grotto's cliffpsan is the route/problem, facing southwest.

content.description:
Nice thin face climbing, with crimps and slopey un-huecos, lead to a cool bulge that will suck you into being harder than it needs to be. It's pretty easy to lead past the 5.6, to TR this and

The Bottom Line

.
content.protection: 5-6 bolts.
content.location: It is the leftmost of three routes, with two anchors, early on your right entering the canyon. This one starts on the left block, not the bigger ledge on the right.

content.description:
U2RNXS is called the "longest and strangest climb in the Rock Garden" in D'Antonio's book.  I'm not sure it's strange, but it is long for a Penitente climb.  It does have a variety of different moves on some cool rock though.

To find it, head right from where the Rock Garden access trail ends.  The climb is on the left near the mouth of the canyon.

The start has a balancy traverse left, then head up using a system of huge huecos past several clips.  The crux comes at you two bolts before the anchor - a crimpy section through a bulge.
content.protection: [8] bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.

content.description: Time in Disguse has cool stemming up a black water groove to a crux move near the top.
content.protection: Five bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: It is just right of I Guano You.

content.description: The crux is passing the third bolt. This has good slab climbing and excellent protection.
content.protection: Six bolts to chain anchors.
content.location: Start with boulder climbing up (easy) to a high first bolt.

content.description:
Start just right of

Otto

climbing excellent pockets up great rock. Originally a 2 bolt climb, this is now well-protected with 4 bolts. It is one of the best .11s in The Garden.
content.protection:
4 bolts, it shares its 4th bolt and anchor with

Otto

.
content.location:
This is just right of

Otto

and has brown bolts.

content.description: This is a super-fun, easy, fairly long, frictiony face, with a great position in the canyon.  A hard start can be bypassed on the right. This is Route #19 in D'Antonio's guides (1999:36 and 1994:20).  The name of the route is sadly misspelled in the 1999 guidebook.
content.protection: Six bolts to a 2-bolt anchor with chains.
content.location:
From the roadside parking, this route is on a buttress on the right about 100 yards up the canyon.  It ascends the nose of the buttress, just right of

The Bottom Line

, and one could probably go past the Geritol chains to set a toprope on The Bottom Line as well.

content.description: This is not in the Rock Garden proper, it is on the hillside filled with boulders just west of the RG parking. This is the awesome, highball splitter with the gnarly rock in the landing.
content.protection: A few pads and a spotter.
content.location: From the Rock Garden parking, walk west down the road for about 100 yards, then walk straight uphill.

content.description:
This is supposedly an electric climb.

It is on SLVCA's long bolt replacement list.
content.protection: 4 old bolts and an old 2-bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is left of

U2RINXS

105762210.

content.description:
This is the roof climb 50 yards west of

Super Crack

. It starts standing with a few easy moves to a crimp rail, make a big throw to the ledge, and then head slightly left for a proper topout.
content.protection: A lot of pads and a spotter. The landing isn't flat.
content.location:
It is 50 yards west of

Super Crack

in the big roof.

content.description: The rock quality gets better up higher. This has technical arete climbing.
content.protection: 4 ASCA glue-ins and a Mussy hook anchor, equipped by SLV Climbers Alliance 4/26/19.
content.location: It is on the first prow as you enter the canyon from the roadside parking.

content.description: This is a nice V7 boulder problem on pinches and crimps. After you crank the boulder problem, you're "home free" or whatever that means. It's like 5.11 from 2nd bolt to the anchor. Don't get me wrong, I'm glad this route actually has an anchor, but the anchor is in a strange spot. This is a worth doing route because of the cool holds at the start.
content.protection: 4 bolts. 2 bolt anchor over the top in a hueco.
content.location:
This route is 20 feet right of

Copacetic

.

content.description: Climb through the unique, fish scale underclings to arrive at the bulgy crux. Pull the insecure and sequential crux to gain the upper seam. Fun and continuous seam climbing (5.11 seam crux) will get you to the anchor.
content.protection: 8 bolts and 2 bolt anchor with Mussy hooks. New ASCA bolts were installed in '20.
content.location:
Located on the steep wall around the corner (to the left) from the obvious

Organic Gardening

crack, Sniff climbs the right side of the wall through the underclings and into the tall seam. Check out the group

topo

.

content.description: Climb a fun, overhanging start on jugs into the scoop to a heady finish.
content.protection: A few pads a spotters would probably be wise.
content.location:
This is described in P. Benningfield's "

Colorado Bouldering Mountains

".

content.description:
Perhaps it is stretching to post three stars for Rude Mood, but this route is a personal favorite of mine.

A couple of hundred feet past the second drainage is a chocolate colored buttress that is carved out as something of an inset that is part of a left-facing corner system.

Start climbing in the slot on the right and try not to stem too much. There are good hands deep in the slot that allow you to move upwards without the stem, however, the stem is almost too logical to be avoided and it is a toss-up as to how much it affects the over-all grade. It is also highly rationale to bail out right on a ledge system at 30 feet for a complete rest. To keep up the continuity, avoid the rest. Tricky and fingery climbing puts you back on the face for 35 more feet of continuous edge climbing.

Fairness would drop a star for the possibility of steming off the ground and resting at mid point. Nonetheless, this route is too cool to lose any points - analogous to the beautiful coed begging for grades, who can refuse?  You can cheapen the date a bit further by scrambling over the top to toss a TR on Dr. Duane on the adjacent left buttress. Three stars for the cool moves, thin and technical edging, continuity, good stone, and well reasoned pro.
content.protection: Seven or eight draws and a rope.

content.description: This is a so-so route with one little hard move down low.  It is mainly a decent place to hang out in some shade, have fun, and climb these 2 moderate lines with inexperienced or out of shape friends.
content.protection: Bolts.
content.location:
This is the right of two routes (with

Buffalo Chips

) on the slab to climber's left and around the buttress from

Delusions of Grandeur

.  They are kind of hidden by a tree until you have walked slightly further up-canyon.

content.description:
This route shares the same slab start as

The Terror

, but where the wall turns steep, The Reckoning climbs the beautiful prow 15 feet right of

The Terror

. A tricky sequence up perfect pockets on perfect rock gains the anchors. There are no sharp holds on this one!
content.protection: 3 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor with Mussy hooks.
content.location:
It is 15 feet right of

The Terror

.

content.description:
This climb is left of

Fine Young Canibals

. It starts off a fat ledge with a high first bolt. This route has good rock and interesting moves, BUT there [was] no anchor, and topping it out [was] no fun. I post this route as a warning, that bailer is on 3rd bolt for a reason.

Per

Wes O'Rourke

: this route is now well protected with a lower first bolt. It climbs the clean wall on perfect pockets all the way! This thing is on you the whole time, so stay focused and crank the continuous moves all the way to the new ASCA anchor.
content.protection:
4 bolts and [previously] a 2 bolt anchor with rap rings. These were up to ASCA standards as of 4-21-19.

Per

Angela Lee

: the new first bolt was added to protect first PG-13 move. Originally this climb had no anchors. New anchors with rap rings were added in 2014(?) as part of the Penitente rebolting project.The 2-bolt Mussy hooks were equipped by SLV Climbers Alliance on 5/9/2020. All of the hardware was donated by the ASCA.
content.location:
It is 40 feet left of that trash pile

Fine Young Canibals

.

Per

Wes O'Rourke

: it ascends the pockets through the otherwise blank patina panel.

content.description: Pick Pocket is a classic mixed climb for the SLV. Climb past one bolt to reach a large ledge underneath the pocketed face with a small finger crack above. A hard boulder problem on pockets leads to a few more difficult moves protected by gear in the small crack. The gear is pretty bad until you get above the second horizontal crack.
content.protection: 4 bolts, small wires and cams, and a 2 bolt anchor with Mussy hooks.
content.location:
This climb is near the Carnero Creek Road and just to the left of the cave where The Living Years and

Hot Chocolate

are.

content.description: Penal Code has a high first bolt - a stickclip recommended. Begin with a bouldery start to a good finger crack, gain the ledge, and continue up the "shaft" of the route.
content.protection: 6 ASCA glue-in bolts and a Mussy Hook anchor equipped by SLV Climbers Alliance 5/17/20.
content.location:
It is around the corner from

You're Busted

.

climbs.name: Pardon My French
climbs.fa: Allen Law, Wes O'Rourke, Ike Manobla

content.description:
Climb a bouldery start and nice slab on sweet rock to funky, hueco face just to the right of

Organic Gardening

.
content.protection: Bolts.

content.description: Fire up the steep face with the crux coming gaining the obvious dish.
content.protection: Five bolts to chain anchors.
content.location:
It is the second route right of

You're Busted

.

content.description: This was named after a dead porcupine found at the base of the route. It has great technical climbing.
content.protection: 4 ASCA glue-ins and a Mussy hook anchor; equipped by SLV Climbers Alliance 4/6/19.
content.location:
It is next to

Slapstick

.

content.description: A wide start leads to splitter fingers with an occasional hand jam pod to rest. Place great pro, and fire the crux bulge to a bolted anchor. If you're solid at the grade, a #5 is not necessary for the start but would certainly make things feel more casual.
content.protection: A standard rack.
content.location:
This is the obvious splitter a few routes right of

Just Do It

.

content.description:
From the

Super Crack

and

Slinky + Escalator

, walk west ~200 yards till you find an overhanging refrigerator. This is No Honor, it starts sitting belie the roof and climbs the roof via narrow compression.
content.protection: 3 pads or so. It has a flat landing for the business, but it downslopes for the top portion.
content.location:
It is ~200 yards west of

Super Crack

.

content.protection: 3 (now 4) bolts to anchors.

content.description:
This is not bad climbing, but it is wandering and discontinuous.  Nevertheless, it is a fun warm-up.  Two climbs to the left of the obvious dihedral that is

Copacetic

, Ninos y Viejos begins right off the trail as opposed to the ledge system higher up.
content.protection:
6 bolts to a two-bolt anchor.

Per

mike and steve

: 2 bolts have been removed. Be warned, bring small pro & prepare to run out.

content.description: Climb straight up the face through the obvious "Cyclops" holes to a highball topout.
content.protection: Be careful.
content.location:
This is described in P. Benningfield's "

Colorado Bouldering Mountains

".

content.description: This is a really nice slab route with the crux getting past the third bolt.
content.protection: Four bolts to a chain anchor.
content.location:
It is the third route right of

You're Busted

.

content.description: Bob originally put this up on gear and 1 pin.  The route goes up the crack system and tops out right. The anchors on the left is Lycra-Phobic, 5.13b
content.protection: 4 bolts and a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: From the roadside parking area, hike down the main trail and take the left fork to a neat side canyon with the other unsorted routes. The route is on your left.

content.description:
As far as locating the route, the best I can suggest is approaching from Penitente and looking straight ahead as you enter Rock Garden proper.  As a 5.9 leader, my eyes went straight to the route - a steep slab & rather long route for the area.

The start can be made a bit easier by staying in the left hand groove / crack in order to clip the first (and second?) bolt(s).  Trust your feet & keep moving up.  This is very fun and fairly sustained.  It is a great reason to hike into the Rock Garden & start exploring.
content.protection: 8 bolts + anchor.

content.description: Bear hug the steep pillar on some sweet holds. If you cheat left into the chimney, you'll be rewarded with bat guano. When the angle eases, cruise the crimp ladder to the top.
content.protection: 6 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor with Mussy hooks. It has glue-in lead bolts and all new ASCA hardware as of 2020.
content.location:
This route climbs the pillar between the two chimneys to the left of

Do the Right Thing

. See the topo photo.

content.description:
Just Say No to Nancy has steep, well-protected climbing right off the deck that leads to a crux at 2/3 height and transitions to lower angle terrain and a little slabe to the coldshuts.

It is a fun route and is worth doing.
content.protection:
Quickdraws.

Ed. Some may want a few pieces of gear in the 0.3-2" range.
content.location: Look for a tall featureless wall near where the Penitente trail comes into the Rock Garden in the canyon. There is a small, steep fissure/dihedral-like feature on the left side and a line of bolts to the immediate right going up to a couple of closely spaced, very chalked up underclings/pockets at 3/4 height. This is the route.

content.description: This climb ascends a big, overhanging prow with huge glue ins and chipped pockets. It has good stone but has had some abuse and neglect.
content.protection: 7 bolts.
content.location:
This is just before

Jugalicious

. The route ascends the prow to the right of the green lichen of

Do the Right Thing

.

content.description:
Jugalicious is just left of the

Copasetic

dihedral.  It begins off the ledge system 25' above the trail at a single-bolt anchor.  Step out left and up the pocketed wall to a roof.  Pull this with an undercling and a crimp - harder if you're short.
content.protection: Four bolts to a two-bolt anchor.

content.description:
This is a short, crimpy route left of

Ligneous Embracer

(there is 1 route between them). It climbs the dark overhang via pockets and crimps with the crux right at the top. I thought it was great.
content.protection: 4 bolts.
content.location:
This is left of

Ligneous Embracer

. There is one route between them, Uncle Lew 5.12c.

content.description: There are continuous crux moves on this short route. It is fun and well worth the effort. It sports new ASCA bolts and Mussy hook anchors as of 2019.
content.protection: 4 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor with Mussy hooks. New bolts were installed by the SLV Climbers Alliance with support from the ASCA.
content.location: Near the end of the canyon to the left of the hanging garden, look for a steep bulge at the top and flakes down low.

content.description: This easy warm-up ascends a short buttress. This is Route #87 in D'Antonio (1999:46-47).
content.protection: Three bolts to a top anchor with two cold-shuts.
content.location: From the roadside parking, this buttress is in the first side canyon on the left, ca. 125 yards from the road. Follow the side canyon about 50 yards, and the buttress is in the canyon bottom on the left, about 50 feet shy of a nice ponderosa pine at the canyon head.

content.description: Hot Chocolate is one of the best 5.12s in the canyon! A trivial start leads to some hard crimping on patina plates. Pull the big move to the huge hueco, and keep it together through the thin upper crux. This sports new ASCA glue-ins and Mussy hook anchors as of April 2019.
content.protection: 5 quickdraws.
content.location: This climbs directly faces the parking lot and is just to the left of the obvious baby bun formation. It ascends the tall brown face with a large hueco dead in the middle of the route. You have to scramble up into the cave underneath The Living Years to access this climb.

content.description:
Bouldery start to sweet huecos and a couple of optional hand jams up top. Stick clip recommended.

This shares a 4th bolt and anchors with the Unknown Glen Schuler route, 5.10d, to its left.

This is a nice warm-up for the area.
content.protection: There are now 4 ASCA glue-in bolts and Mussy hooks on top. The new bolts were equipped by the SLV Climbers Alliance with support from the ASCA.
content.location: Honeycomb ascends the obvious face full of huecos on the right of the main trail if coming from the Rock Garden parking off CR 41G.

content.description: There is a hard move past the 1st bolt, then it is still sustained, thin edging/slabbing to the anchors.
content.protection:
4 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.

Per

Wes O'Rourke

: the original equipment was replaced by the San Luis Valley Climbers Alliance with new ASCA bolts and Mussy hook anchors as of 2019.
content.location:
About 150 feet left of where the trail hits the garden and just before the trail breaks left to the

Jugalicious

/

Copasetic

area (50 feet left of

Just Do It

with big glue-in bolts). Hanging Garden is the center route on a clean looking face (right route is a 12; left is a single bolt/Leeper hanger horror show....

content.description: Start on top of a boulder.  Grab small holds and pull.  There is a hand crack out left after the second bolt.
content.protection: 3 draws + 2 draws for anchor.

content.description: Climb a crack system past a series of vegetated ledges.
content.protection: Nuts and cams to #4 and coldshut anchors.
content.location: Start 10' right of You're Busted.

content.description:
Immediately left of

Darla

and on the adjacent buttress, FYC climbs up steep terrain on a system of near perfect edges. The climbing is continuous and fairly relentless for the grade. It seemed as though every move was close to 5.11 and the cruxes start coming at you right off the ground. FYC comes highly recommended for the good stone, continuity, and relentless evolution of sequences.
content.protection: Half a dozen draws and a rope.

content.description: This is the first 5.11 established in the SLV. It is a beautiful crack climb that rarely gets climbed. A hard to protect crux mantel at the first piece makes this route committing and a bit spicy. Pull the hard mantel, and enjoy crack climbing from fingers into the wide chimney up high.
content.protection: A trad rack with mostly thin gear with a few wide pieces for the top. I believe we used a black Totem cam to protect the mantel down low. Be careful with this piece as it's flared, and you will deck if it pops.
content.location: It is right where the Rock Garden meets the Carnero Creek Road. If you're looking from the road, it's on the right of the canyon mouth facing the road. It's the only route on the North aspect of the entrance area.

content.description: Fed Ex climbs a short, balancy slab.
content.protection: I think 4 bolts.
content.location:
It is the slabby route just up and right (west) from

I+CN'?

and faces south. Start under a crack that slants up and right.

content.description: This is a great route.
content.protection: 8 bolts and an old 2-bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is left of

California Crack

.

content.description:
Climb the low angle corner to gain the green lichen covered slab up high. Watch the clips and the slight runout to bolt three. Use all of your slab skills to dance up the great holds to the anchors. Check out the top down

photo

.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is the next route to the left of

Just Do It

(the arete with ugly glue-ins) and around the corner from the obvious splitter Organic Gardening.

content.description:
Start out on nice rock and turns chossy at the crux. My partner pulled off six holds from the crux.

Per

Wes O'Rourke

: balancy and slopey climbing brings you to the third bolt and the start of the "business". The wall steepens as you enter some amazing pockets and crimp rails. Punch it through the bouldery crux, and crimp your way up to the anchor!
content.protection: 5 bolts to anchor.
content.location:
This is towards the back of the Rock Garden. Look for a small grassy alcove just past organic gardening crack.

It's a Schu-in

is on the left, and DOA is on the right side of this alcove. See the topo photo.

content.description:
Coming out of the cave just right of

Buffalo Chips

is a very steep line that begins on huge lay-away jugs; this is Delusions, and is aptly named (at least for some of us). Continuous and powerful flake climbing for three bolts leads out of the cave and into gonad-land. This climb is a bit weird in the sense that the pro is so reasonable where the climbing is powerful, but gets really sparse where the climbing gets technical. It is possible to pre-clip a long sling from the bolt above the cave, and this seems very desirable since the run-out comes close on the heels of very pumpy climbing. Pull out of the cave onto a short very technical grey face with reachy moves on good stone. Subsequently, a good horizontal stance can be negotiated via a sizeable pocket. This is followed by more thin edge climbing on near perfect rock. This route might deserve three stars, as consensus demands. The rock coming out of the cave is a bit dubious, but it has held up over the years and may only look as though it will break away. Otherwise, expect excellent climbing, powerful, and pretty scary in the middle - if it is done without pre-placing the draw.
content.protection: Eight draws some gonads, and a rope.

content.description: Shortly before the second drainage coming in from the right is a pair of buttresses with a dark channel between them. Darla climbs the edge of the right of the two buttresses. Excellent and interesting climbing with good continuity leads to a complex sequence that will dump the climber rightward to run the arete for a short way. This is followed by a very interesting and technical slab with as much exposure as you can get on a short cliff. Darla is a fine line and well worth the run. Good continuity, good stone, and excellent pro.
content.protection: Half a dozen draws and a rope.

content.description:
Crack House has a very high first bolt, but it's fairly secure ~5.10 movement to the first clip. Watch for the deck potential between 1st and 2nd bolt.

With blessing from the first ascensionists, SLVCA may add a safety bolt between bolt 1 and 2 after feedback from climbers as to the groundfall potential. Reach out at

slvclimb.org

.
content.protection: 6 ASCA glue-ins and a Mussy anchor equipped by SLV Climbers Alliance 5/17/20.
content.location:
It is left of the very phallic

Penal Code

.

content.description:
10 feet right of

The Reckoning

is a corner with beautiful, white rock. This is Court Jester. Right now it is a scary 2 bolt climb (with BAD bolts), but I am planning on fixing this route. It has good rock with good stemming. If you want to top rope, it you can through my brand new anchor on

The Reckoning

.
content.protection:
It should just be toproped until it gets fixed with new bolts.

Per

Wes O'Rourke

: there are new ASCA bolts and anchor as of 2014.
content.location:
This is 10 feet right of

The Reckoning

, 45 feet left of

The Bottom Line

and

Team Geritol

.

content.description: Copacetic heads up a left-facing corner with huecos and fun stems.  It is located on a piece of rock that is fairly far up-canyon in the Rock Garden - beginning on a ledge 25 feet above the trail.
content.protection: Five bolts to a two-bolt anchor.

content.description: Climb past 4 bolts up blank arete. This is super technical, but it has a couple powerful moves in the mix.
content.protection: 4 bolts.

content.description:
This is the super sweet, overhanging arete 10 yards up the hill from

No Honor Amongst Thieves

. It starts on the lowest holds you can grab (as a mortal) and climbs directly up the arete.
content.protection: 3 pads and webbing to hold the pads in place.
content.location:
It is 10 yards uphill from

No Honor Amongst Thieves

.

content.description: This is a trad-protected route that has a diverse set of holds (flakes, pockets, edges, etc.).  There didn't really seem to be a well-defined crux.  Some poor quality rock at the top detracts from the overall aesthetics of the route.  Otherwise, this is a stellar line.
content.protection:
Wired stoppers and cams to 2.5".

There is an anchor at the top consisting of two bolts that are nearly in-line with each other vertically but offset by an appropriate amount. The bolts each have welded cold-shuts that are linked by a section of chain which seems to offer only a single link to thread a rope through. I threaded both cold-shuts and lowered off with no problems.

Per

Angela Lee

: a 2-bolt ASCA Mussy hook anchor was updated and equipped by Nate Liles & SLVCA on 4/10/19.
content.location:
This route is located to the right of another trad line with a wide fingers start leading to a chimney.  Both of these trad lines are located to the right of "

U2RNXS

" on the tall, free-standing formation that is closest to the pullout for the Rock Garden.

content.description:
Across the canyon from

U2RNXS

is a sweet looking pillar/fin. This route climbs the face for a few bolts then the best part, the overhanging arête at the top! This route is rated 5.12a/b in the guide, but it felt way harder, like .12c, but maybe I missed something. The position at the top portion of the route is unbeatable. Not sure what to say about that "anchor", it is a mess.
content.protection: 4 bolts.
content.location:
This is on the pillar across the canyon from

U2RNXS

.

content.description: Just before the first prominant drainage system from the right is a blocky formation with a classic long slab. Buffalo Chips runs the middle of the slab in 70 feet of fine, technical smearing with a bulgy crux shortly before the anchor. This line offers some of the best moderate climbing in the canyon and is recommended for anyone getting started on the sharp end or working through the numbers game.
content.protection: Half a dozen draws and a rope.

content.description: The crux may be getting off the ground, but the whole route is thin, sustained, and fun.
content.protection: 6 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This the steep slab/face to the left of

Team Geritol

(Genital).  A couple huecos and lots of small crimps lead you up the bolt line.  Could be painful if you blow the 2nd clip.  It's possible to "cheat" by moving out right of the little depression to a flake, but straight up the bolt line is "all there".

content.description: A short face climb in a nice little secluded side canyon. Not remarkable, but it is a fairly easy 5.9, and worth doing to warm up. This is Route #84 in D'Antonio (1999:46), although no topos are in the guide book.
content.protection:
3 bolts to a 2-bolt top anchor with chains (shared with the

Wallrus

route to the left).
content.location: From the roadside parking area, this route is in the first side canyon on the left, ca. 125 yards from the road. Follow the side canyon about 55 yards to a nice ponderosa pine near the canyon head. Just past the pine, and before you come to a nice spruce/fir, turn left into a tributary canyon. Pass about 10 yards through some chokecherry, and the face is on the righthand side of the canyon. Big Brett ascends the righthand side of the little face. A slightly overhanging crack with cold-shut anchors at the top is just to the left of the Big Brett face.

content.description: Getting past the first bolt on sharp small holds is the crux. This has great climbing all the way to the anchor.
content.protection: Four bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is on the left side of the

Honeycomb

alcove.

content.description:
Baby Face Right has thin face climbing marred by the poor anchor situation. As of September 2019, there is no hanger on either anchor bolt, and the 3 bolts on route are old enough to be sketchy. Proceed with caution for now. This would be a reasonable, if short, warm-up if the hardware is replaced.

While I didn't climb it, this climb's twin, Baby Bun Left, also appears to have a suboptimal anchor and bolting situation.
content.protection: 3 bolts to NO ANCHOR.
content.location: This is on a prominent, overgrown ledge about 60 feet up canyon from the U2RINXS Tower.
